review_title: Hardworking Group with Longtime Employees & Dedicated Leadership
pros:
There's a reason many employees have been here for decades. Working here, you can make a tangible difference by supporting the optics and photonics academic research and industry innovations that make the world a better connected and more inclusive place.

The building is modern and has a great staff lounge with nice views of the city. Open concept and glass walls, but good sound-proofing mostly. In-house IT are responsive and provide good equipment and technology solutions.

Work flow can be varied, but most major time commitments can be seen on the horizon and planned for. 

Leaders are extremely dedicated to the organization. They ask incisive questions, which can be difficult for some people. It's nice that the CEO takes care to check in with people — there are so many places where that would not be true.

Benefits are above-average and HR team is very talented at in-house HR functions. Probably need a modernized recruitment plan to improve on certain diversity topics in leadership, but generally a more representative-than-average environment.
cons:
Some working styles are difficult to accommodate. Staffing plans that don't have clearly delineated responsibilities, very last minute requests from people who didn't plan ahead. Some people avoid working at all costs, knowing others will take it on for them, contributing to burnout and uneven workloads and even more last minute requests. Some processes also get held up by extremely small details, with very little benefit for doing so. Probably not enough payroll dedicated to administrative staff who could handle some of the smaller details that are necessary. However, some people are challenged to delegate anyway.

You have to know who to minimize contact with — there are a few people who might not have job security at other places.

review_title: Working for the Optical Society is challenging but can be very rewarding.
pros: The mission and goals of OSA are ambitious.  The members of the society are dedicated.  Many of your co-workers will be very talented people.  There is great opportunity for advancement if you have the social skills and technical knowledge.  You can accomplish a great deal here if you can avoid being blindsided by the politics.
cons: You must have the political skills and social background to impress the "in" crowd.  OSA tends to reward people with titles instead of money.  Dissent is not tolerated, and honesty is not appreciated. You can survive by doing your job well and never arguing; you can thrive only if you know how to promote your ideas and yourself in a highly politically charged atmosphere.

I chuckle reading these negative posts on here, because it really seems like some of these people have not worked very long in the real world, or must be fresh out of college or immature.  
As mentioned above, is OSA perfect, no but I've worked at places that are much worse than OSA.
cons:
1. Does OSA have high expectations, yes and why shouldn't they have expectations. They do pay you well. 
2. There are negative posts on about worklife balance, and high expectations?  Yes there are  high expectations, but our quality has been recognized around the world. I rather work for a company that has high expectations than a medico company that settles. Worklife balance is not an issue Society wide. This place is a ghost town after 5:30 pm.
